{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2970788,"name":"Mark","username":"mqshaw","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mqshaw/{size}/159985_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-06T09:00:48.558Z","cooked":"

I am trying to communicate a set of values from my C++ code running on the rPi using network tables. But I cannot figure out how to convert my std::vector into an nt::ArrayRef in order to be able to pass it back.

Can someone please guide me.

Here is my code ‚Ä¶

// Setting up NT Keys
const wpi::Twine TableKey = wpi::Twine("Table");
const wpi::Twine LocationKey = wpi::Twine("Locations");

// Setting up Entries
nt::NetworkTableEntry LocationsEntry = nt::NetworkTableInstance::GetDefault().GetTable(TableKey)->GetEntry(LocationKey);

// Example 1D array
size_t array_size = 20;
std::vector <double> doublearray(array_size);
for (int i = 0; i < array_size; i++)
    doublearray[i] = -1.0;

// Not sure what code is needed here to convert from a std::vector to nt::RefArray
nt::RefArray <double> test =  ????

LocationsEntry.SetDoubleArray( test );
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-06T09:00:48.558Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":142,"reads":70,"readers_count":69,"score":729.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396427,"topic_slug":"creating-network-table-entries-using-c-and-arrayref","display_username":"Mark","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49590,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/creating-network-table-entries-using-c-and-arrayref/396427/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":2970791,"name":"Mr.R^2","username":"Mr.R_2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mr.r_2/{size}/89723_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-06T10:22:38.848Z","cooked":"

I do not know Cpp that well, but would an array of vectors actually be a 2d array? If that is the case, I could see why this could fail.

I wonder if you casted the vectors as strings and then casted them back to vectors on the robot (and/or driver station) if that would work.

Mind you, I know little about the two libraries in question so I could be totally wrong.

Also, there could be a better way to accomplish this.

We have code which just passes the vector itself into SetDoubleArray. It compiles, I haven‚Äôt tested it in a while but give it a try on in your code.

Hello @Mr.R_2 ,
A 1D array can be a vector, think of a 1D-Look-up table that is of length 20 (in my example). The code that generates the array as a std::vector is fine, I am having a hard time knowing how to convert it to an ArrayRef.

I have reviewed the documentation that @Joe_Ross suggested many times, but cannot figure out how to make it work.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-06T14:28:45.473Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":42,"readers_count":41,"score":33.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":396427,"topic_slug":"creating-network-table-entries-using-c-and-arrayref","display_username":"Mark","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":30291,"username":"Mr.R_2","name":"Mr.R^2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mr.r_2/{size}/89723_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49590,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/creating-network-table-entries-using-c-and-arrayref/396427/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2970814,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-06T14:34:54.725Z","cooked":"
LocationsEntry.SetDoubleArray( doublearray );

ArrayRef has an implicit conversion from vector, so you can just pass your vector directly, no need to explicitly convert it.

Note: in 2022 ArrayRef is replaced by span (a backport of C++20‚Äôs std::span), but the concept is the same: a std::vector will implicitly convert to a span.

KJaget:

e have code which just passes the vector itself into SetDoubleArray. It compiles, I haven‚Äôt tested it in a while but give it a try on in your code.

Hi Peter,
When I try just passing the vector in directly I get a compilation error. Here is the error

nt::NetworkTableEntry::SetDoubleArray(wpi::ArrayRef<double>)':
../../../lib/wpilib_cameraserver_2021_3_1/include/networktables/NetworkTableEntry.inl:218:13: 
note: parameter passing for argument of type 'wpi::ArrayRef<double>' changed in GCC 7.1

note: parameter passing for argument of type 'wpi::ArrayRef<double>' changed in GCC 7.1    
return SetEntryValue(m_handle, Value::MakeDoubleArray(value));
                              ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^~~~~~~

I dont know what I am missing.

Hi All,

Thank you for your responses, I have tested this using the simulator and can see that the table is being created and updated in the network server as the code is running.

image751√ó74 6.98 KB

Thank you for everyone‚Äôs help.

Just a note for those that may be reading this in the future‚Ä¶

  1. Visual Studio Code and IntelliJ were both telling me that the two data types were not compatible which started me down this path. So, the lesson learned was to try compiling it, and then go from there. I wasted many hours trying to figure out why the IDE was showing an error in my code ‚Ä¶ that would have been saved.

Mark

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-07T15:21:28.502Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":40,"readers_count":39,"score":18.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396427,"topic_slug":"creating-network-table-entries-using-c-and-arrayref","display_username":"Mark","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/e/3/e3a9e1fd04564562545f428a2e76d8d852ba8741.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":49590,"username":"mqshaw","name":"Mark","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mqshaw/{size}/159985_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49590,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/creating-network-table-entries-using-c-and-arrayref/396427/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2971039,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-07T16:25:02.170Z","cooked":"

Something that will hopefully help in the future: as I mentioned earlier, one of the improvements we‚Äôre making in C++ for WPILib 2022 is moving more towards C++ standard library components (or at least standards-track components) for interfaces, particularly as C++17 and C++20 add similar classes to the (very useful) LLVM classes we‚Äôve used to date:

  • wpi::StringRef is being replaced by std::string_view. This is a drop-in replacement for most use cases; std::string_view doesn‚Äôt have all the convenience functions that StringRef did, so we‚Äôve added these as free functions to wpi/StringExtras.h.
  • wpi::ArrayRef is being replaced by wpi::span, which is an exact drop-in for C++20 std::span. We unfortunately can‚Äôt use the C++20 one yet due to lacking compiler support, but this will ease a future transition. Similar to the case for StringRef, span doesn‚Äôt have the same convenience functions as ArrayRef, so we‚Äôve added these as free functions to wpi/SpanExtras.h.
  • wpi::Twine is being replaced by fmtlib. Twine had some nice features and is more efficient in a handful of use cases, but fmtlib is a lot easier to understand, has better docs, will be largely standardized in C++20 as std::format, and has fewer potential trip points for users.

We realize this will cause some short-term pain for teams upgrading, but expect it to pay off over the long term due to better docs / online resources from using standard library components.
